Robust Group Linkage

   Pei Li

Xin Luna Dong

Songtao Guo 11footnotemark: 1

Research conducted at AT&T Labs–Research. University of Zurich peili@ifi.uzh.ch Google Inc. lunadong@google.com LinkedIn Corp. songtao.gg@gmail.com    Andrea Maurino

Divesh Srivastava

University of Milan-Bicocca maurino@disco.unimib.it AT&T Labs-Research divesh@research.att.com
Abstract

We study the problem of group linkage: linking records that refer to entities in the same group. Applications for group linkage include finding businesses in the same chain, finding conference attendees from the same affiliation, finding players from the same team, etc. Group linkage faces challenges not present for traditional record linkage. First, although different members in the same group can share some similar global values of an attribute, they represent different entities so can also have distinct local values for the same or different attributes, requiring a high tolerance for value diversity. Second, groups can be huge (with tens of thousands of records), requiring high scalability even after using good blocking strategies.

We present a two-stage algorithm: the first stage identifies cores containing records that are very likely to belong to the same group, while being robust to possible erroneous values; the second stage collects strong evidence from the cores and leverages it for merging more records into the same group, while being tolerant to differences in local values of an attribute. Experimental results show the high effectiveness and efficiency of our algorithm on various real-world data sets.

1 Introduction

Record linkage aims at linking records that refer to the same real-world entity and it has been extensively studied in the past years (surveyed in [8, 19]). In this paper we study a related but different problem that we call group linkage: linking records that refer to entities in the same group.

One major motivation for our work comes from identifying business chains–connected business entities that share a brand name and provide similar products and services (e.g., Walmart, McDonald’s). With the advent of the Web and mobile devices, we are observing a boom in local search; that is, searching local businesses under geographical constraints. Local search engines include Google Maps, Yahoo! Local, YellowPages, yelp, ezlocal, etc. The knowledge of business chains can have a big economic value to local search engines, as it allows users to search by business chain, allows search engines to render the returned results by chains, allows data collectors to clean and enrich information within the same chain, allows the associated review system to connect reviews on branches of the same chain, and allows sales people to target potential customers. Business listings are rarely associated with specific chains explicitly in real-world business-listing collections, so we need to identify the chains. Sharing the same name, phone number, or URL domain name can all serve as evidence of belonging to the same chain. However, for US businesses alone there are tens of thousands of chains and as we show soon, we cannot easily develop any rule set that applies to all chains.

We are also motivated by applications where we need to find people from the same organization, such as counting conference attendees from the same affiliation, counting papers by authors from the same institution, and finding players of the same team. The organization information is often missing, incomplete, or simply too heterogeneous to be recognized as the same (e.g., “International Business Machines Corporation”, “IBM Corp.”, “IBM”, “IBM Research Labs”, “IBM-Almaden”, etc., all refer to the same organization). Contact phones, email addresses, and mailing addresses of people all provide extra evidence for group linkage, but they can also vary for different people even in the same organization.

Group linkage faces challenges not present for traditional record linkage. First, although different members in the same group can share some similar global values of an attribute, they represent different entities so can also have distinct local values for the same or different attributes. For example, different branches in the same business chain can provide different local phone numbers, different addresses, etc. It is non-trivial to distinguish such differences from various representations for the same value and sometimes erroneous values in the data. Second, there are often millions of records for group linkage, and a group can contain tens of thousands of members. A good blocking strategy should put these tens of thousands of records in the same block; but performing record linkage via traditional pairwise comparisons within such huge blocks can be very expensive. Thus, scalability is a big challenge. We use the following example of identifying business chains throughout the paper for illustration.

Example 1.1

We consider a set of 18M real-world business listings in the US extracted from Yellowpages.com, each describing a business by its name, phone number, URL domain name, location, and category. Our algorithm automatically finds 600K business chains and 2.7M listings that belong to these chains. Table 1 lists the largest five chains we found. We observe that (1) each chain contains up to 22K different branch stores, (2) different branches from the same chain can have a large variety of names, phone numbers, and URL domain names, and (3) even chains of similar sizes can have very different numbers of distinct URLs (same for other attributes). Thus, rule-based linkage can hardly succeed and scalability is a necessity.

Table 2 shows a set of 20 business listings (with some abstraction) in this data set. After investigating their webpages manually, we find that r1−r18subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟18r_{1}-r_{18} belong to three business chains: Ch1={r1−r10},Ch2={r11−r15}formulae-sequencesubscriptCh1subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟10subscriptCh2subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟15\mbox{Ch}_{1}=\{r_{1}-r_{10}\},\mbox{Ch}_{2}=\{r_{11}-r_{15}\}, and Ch3={r16−r18}subscriptCh3subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18\mbox{Ch}_{3}=\{r_{16}-r_{18}\}; r19subscript𝑟19r_{19} and r20subscript𝑟20r_{20} do not belong to any chain. Note the slightly different names for businesses in chain Ch1subscriptCh1\mbox{Ch}_{1}; also note that r13subscript𝑟13r_{13} is integrated from different sources and contains two URLs, one (tacocasatexas) being wrong.

Simple linkage rules do not work well on this data set. For example, if we require only high similarity on name for chain identification, we may wrongly decide that r11−r20subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟20r_{11}-r_{20} all belong to the same chain as they share a popular restaurant name Taco Casa. Traditional linkage strategies do not work well either. If we apply Swoosh-style linkage [27] and iteratively merge records with high similarity on name and shared phone or URL, we can wrongly merge Ch2subscriptCh2\mbox{Ch}_{2} and Ch3subscriptCh3\mbox{Ch}_{3} because of the wrong URL from r13subscript𝑟13r_{13}. If we require high similarity between listings on name, phone, URL, category, we may either split r6−r8subscript𝑟6subscript𝑟8r_{6}-r_{8} out of chain Ch1subscriptCh1\mbox{Ch}_{1} because of their different local phone numbers, or learn a low weight for phone but split r9−r10subscript𝑟9subscript𝑟10r_{9}-r_{10} out of chain Ch1subscriptCh1\mbox{Ch}_{1} since sharing the same phone number, the major evidence, is downweighted. □□\Box

The key idea in our solution is to find strong evidence that can glue group members together, while being tolerant to differences in values specific for individual group members. For example, we wish to reward sharing of primary values, such as primary phone numbers or URL domain names for chain identification, but would not penalize differences from local values, such as locations, local phone numbers, and even categories. For this purpose, our algorithm proceeds in two stages. First, we identify cores containing records that are very likely to belong to the same group. Second, we collect strong evidence from the resulting cores, such as primary phone numbers and URL domain names in business chains, based on which we cluster the cores and remaining records into groups. The use of cores and strong evidence distinguishes our clustering algorithm from traditional clustering techniques for record linkage. In this process, it is crucial that core generation makes very few false positives even in the presence of erroneous values, such that we can avoid ripple effect on clustering later. Our algorithm is designed to ensure efficiency and scalability.

The group linkage problem we study in this paper is different from the group linkage in [18, 23], which decides similarity between pre-specified groups of records. Our goal is to find records that belong to the same group and we make three contributions.

  1. 1.

    We study core generation in presence of erroneous data. Our core is robust in the sense that even if we remove a few possibly erroneous records from a core, we still have strong evidence that the rest of the records in the core must belong to the same group.

  2. 2.

    We then reduce the group linkage problem into clustering cores and remaining records. Our clustering algorithm leverages strong evidence collected from cores and meanwhile is tolerant to value variety of records in the same group.

  3. 3.

    We conducted experiments on two real-world data sets in different domains, showing high efficiency and effectiveness of our algorithms.

Note that we assume prior to group linkage, we first conduct record linkage (e.g., [15]). Our experiments show that minor mistakes for record linkage do not significantly affect the results of group linkage, and records that describe the same entity but fail to be merged in the record-linkage step are often put into the same group. We plan to study how to combine record linkage and group linkage to improve the results of both in the future.

In the rest of the paper, Section 2 discusses related work. Section 3 defines the problem and provides an overview of our solution. Sections 4-5 describe the two stages in our solution. Section 6 describes experimental results. Section 7 concludes.

2 Related Work

Record linkage has been extensively studied in the past (surveyed in [8, 19]). Traditional linkage techniques aim at linking records that refer to the same real-world entity, so implicitly assume value consistency between records that should be linked. Group linkage is different in that it aims at linking records that refer to different entities in the same group. The variety of individual entities requires better use of strong evidence and tolerance on different values even within the same group. These two features differentiate our work from any previous linkage technique.

For record clustering in linkage, existing work may apply the transitive rule [17], or do match-and-merge [27], or reduce it to an optimization problem [16]. Our work is different in that our core-identification algorithm aims at being robust to a few erroneous records; and our clustering algorithm emphasizes leveraging the strong evidence collected from the cores.

For record-similarity computation, existing work can be rule based
 [17], classification based [11], or distance based [6]. There has also been work on weight (or model) learning from labeled data [11, 29]. Our work is different in that in addition to learning a weight for each attribute, we also learn a weight for each value based on whether it serves as important evidence for the group. Note that some previous works are also tolerant to different values but leverage evidence that may not be available in our contexts: [10] is tolerant to schema heterogeneity from different relations by specifying matching rules; [15] is tolerant to possibly false values by considering agreement between different data providers; [21] is tolerant to out-of-date values by considering time stamps; we are tolerant to diversity within the same group.

Two-stage clustering has been proposed in the IR and machine learning community [1, 20, 22, 28, 30]; however, they identify cores in different ways. Techniques in [20, 28] consider a core as a single record, either randomly selected or selected according to the weighted degrees of nodes in the graph. Techniques in [30] generate cores using agglomerative clustering but can be too conservative and miss strong evidence. Techniques in [1] identify cores as bi-connected components, where removing any node would not disconnect the graph. Although this corresponds to the 1-robustness requirement in our solution (defined in Section 4), they generate overlapping clusters; it is not obvious how to derive non-overlapping clusters in applications such as business-chain identification and how to extend their techniques to guarantee k𝑘k-robustness. Finally, techniques in [20, 22] require knowledge of the number of clusters for one of the stages, so do not directly apply in our context. We compare with these methods whenever applicable in experiments (Section 6), showing that our algorithm is robust in presence of erroneous values and consistently generates high-accuracy results on data sets with different features.

Finally, we distinguish our work from the group linkage in [18, 23], which has different goals. On et al. [23] decided similarity between pre-specified groups of records and the group-entity relationship is many-to-many (e.g., authors and papers). Huang [18] decided whether two pre-specified groups of records from different data sources refer to the same group by analysis of social network. Our goal is to find records that belong to the same group.

3 Overview

This section formally defines the group linkage problem and provides an overview of our solution.

3.1 Problem definition

Let 𝐑𝐑\bf R be a set of records that describe real-world entities by a set of attributes 𝐀𝐀\bf A. For each record r∈𝐑𝑟𝐑r\in\bf R, we denote by r.Aformulae-sequence𝑟𝐴r.A its value on attribute A∈𝐀𝐴𝐀A\in\bf A. Sometimes a record may contain erroneous or missing values.

We consider the group linkage problem; that is, finding records that represent entities belonging to the same real-world group. As an example application, we wish to find business chains–a set of business entities with the same or highly similar names that provide similar products and services (e.g., Walmart, Home Depot, Subway and McDonald’s).111http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chain__\_store. We focus on non-overlapping groups, which often hold in applications.

Definition 3.1 (Group linkage)

Given a set 𝐑𝐑\bf R of records, group linkage identifies a set of clusters 𝐂𝐇𝐂𝐇\bf CH of records in 𝐑𝐑\bf R, such that (1) records that represent real-world entities in the same group belong to one cluster, and (2) records from different groups belong to different clusters. □□\Box

Example 3.2

Consider records in Example 1.1, where each record describes a business store (at a distinct location) by attributes name, phone, URL, location, and category.

The ideal solution to the group linkage problem contains 5 clusters: Ch1={r1−r10}subscriptCh1subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟10\mbox{Ch}_{1}=\{r_{1}-r_{10}\}, Ch2={r11−r15}subscriptCh2subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟15\mbox{Ch}_{2}=\{r_{11}-r_{15}\}, Ch3={r16−r18}subscriptCh3subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18\mbox{Ch}_{3}=\{r_{16}-r_{18}\}, Ch4={r19}subscriptCh4subscript𝑟19\mbox{Ch}_{4}=\{r_{19}\}, and Ch5={r20}subscriptCh5subscript𝑟20\mbox{Ch}_{5}=\{r_{20}\}. Among them, Ch2subscriptCh2\mbox{Ch}_{2} and Ch3subscriptCh3\mbox{Ch}_{3} represent two different chains with the same name. □□\Box

3.2 Overview of our solution

Group linkage is related to but different from traditional record linkage because it essentially looks for records that represent entities in the same group, rather than records that represent exactly the same entity. Different members in the same group often share a certain amount of commonality (e.g., common name, primary phone, and URL domain of chain stores), but meanwhile can also have a lot of differences (e.g., different addresses, local phone numbers, and local URL domains); thus, we need to allow much higher variety in some attribute values to avoid false negatives. On the other hand, as we have shown in Example 1.1, simply lowering our requirement on similarity of records or similarity of a few attributes in clustering can lead to a lot of false positives.

The key intuition of our solution is to distinguish between strong evidence and weak evidence. For example, different branches in the same business chain often share the same URL domain name and those in North America often share the same 1-800 phone number. Thus, a URL domain or phone number shared among many business listings with highly similar names can serve as strong evidence for chain identification. In contrast, a phone number shared by only a couple of business entities is much weaker evidence, since one might be an erroneous or out-of-date value.

To facilitate leveraging strong evidence, our solution consists of two stages. The first stage collects records that are highly likely to belong to the same group; for example, a set of business listings with the same name and phone number are very likely to be in the same chain. We call the results cores of the groups; from them we can collect strong evidence such as name, primary phone number, and primary URL domain of chains. The key goal of this stage is to be robust against erroneous values and make as few false positives as possible, so we can avoid identifying strong evidence wrongly and causing incorrect ripple effect later; however, we need to keep in mind that being too strict can miss important strong evidence.

The second stage clusters cores and remaining records into groups according to the discovered strong evidence. It decides whether several cores belong to the same group, and whether a record that does not belong to any core actually belongs to some group. It also employs weak evidence, but treats it differently from strong evidence. The key intuition of this stage is to leverage the strong evidence and meanwhile be tolerant to diversity of values in the same group, so we can reduce false negatives made in the first stage.

We next illustrate our approach for business-chain identification.

Example 3.3

Continue with the motivating example. In the first stage we generate three cores: Cr1={r1−r7},Cr2={r14,r15},Cr3={r16−r18}formulae-sequencesubscriptCr1subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟7formulae-sequencesubscriptCr2subscript𝑟14subscript𝑟15subscriptCr3subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18\mbox{Cr}_{1}=\{r_{1}-r_{7}\},\mbox{Cr}_{2}=\{r_{14},r_{15}\},\mbox{Cr}_{3}=\{r_{16}-r_{18}\}. Records r1−r7subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟7r_{1}-r_{7} are in the same core because they have the same name, five of them (r1−r5subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟5r_{1}-r_{5}) share the same phone number 808 and five of them (r3−r7subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟7r_{3}-r_{7}) share the same URL homedepot. Similar for the other two cores. Note that r13subscript𝑟13r_{13} does not belong to any core, because one of its URLs is the same as that of r11−r12subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟12r_{11}-r_{12}, and one is the same as that of r16−r18subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18r_{16}-r_{18}, but except name, there is no other common information between these two groups of records. To avoid mistakes, we defer the decision on r13subscript𝑟13r_{13}. Indeed, recall that tacocasatexas is a wrong value for r13subscript𝑟13r_{13}. For a similar reason, we defer the decision on r12subscript𝑟12r_{12}.

In the second stage, we generate groups–business chains. We merge r8−r10subscript𝑟8subscript𝑟10r_{8}-r_{10} with core Cr1subscriptCr1\mbox{Cr}_{1}, because they have similar names and share either the primary phone number or the primary URL. We also merge r11−r13subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟13r_{11}-r_{13} with core Cr2subscriptCr2\mbox{Cr}_{2}, because (1) r12−r13subscript𝑟12subscript𝑟13r_{12}-r_{13} share the primary phone 900 with Cr2subscriptCr2\mbox{Cr}_{2}, and (2) r11subscript𝑟11r_{11} shares the primary URL tacocasa with r12−r13subscript𝑟12subscript𝑟13r_{12}-r_{13}. We do not merge Cr2subscriptCr2\mbox{Cr}_{2} and Cr3subscriptCr3\mbox{Cr}_{3} though, because they share neither the primary phone nor the primary URL. We do not merge r19subscript𝑟19r_{19} or r20subscript𝑟20r_{20} to any core, because there is again not much strong evidence. We thus obtain the ideal result. □□\Box

To facilitate this two-stage solution, we find attributes that provide evidence for group identification and classify them into three categories.

  • •

    Common-value attribute: We call an attribute A𝐴A a common-value attribute if all entities in the same group have the same or highly similar A𝐴A-values. Such attributes include business-name for chain identification and organization for organization linkage.

  • •

    Dominant-value attribute: We call an attribute A𝐴A a dominant-value attribute if entities in the same group often share one or a few primary A𝐴A-values (but there can also exist other less-common values), and these values are seldom used by entities outside the group. Such attributes include phone and URL-domain for chain identification, and office-address, phone-prefix, and email-server for organization linkage.

  • •

    Multi-value attribute: We call the rest of the attributes mutli-value attributes as there is often a many-to-many relationship between groups and values of these attributes. Such attributes include category for chain identification.

The classification can be either learned from training data based on cardinality of attribute values, or performed by domain experts since there are typically only a few such attributes.

We describe core identification in Section 4 and group linkage in Section 5. Our algorithms require common-value and dominant-value attributes, which typically exist for groups in practice. While we present the algorithms for the setting of one machine, a lot of components of our algorithms can be easily parallelized in Hadoop infrastructure [24, 4]; it is not the focus of the paper and we briefly describe the opportunities in Section 6.4.

4 Core Identification

The first stage of our solution creates cores consisting of records that are very likely to belong to the same group. The key goal in core identification is to be robust to possible erroneous values. This section starts with presenting the criteria we wish the cores to meet (Section 4.1), then describes how we efficiently construct similarity graphs to facilitate core finding (Section 4.2), and finally gives the algorithm for core identification (Section 4.3). Note that the notations in this section can be slightly different from those in Graph Theory.

4.1 Criteria for a core

At the first stage we wish to make only decisions that are highly likely to be correct; thus, we require that each core contains only highly similar records, and different cores are fairly different and easily distinguishable from each other. In addition, we wish that our results are robust even in the presence of a few erroneous values in the data. In the motivating example, r1−r7subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟7r_{1}-r_{7} form a good core, because 808 and homedepot are very popular values among these records. In contrast, r13−r18subscript𝑟13subscript𝑟18r_{13}-r_{18} do not form a good core, because records r14−r15subscript𝑟14subscript𝑟15r_{14}-r_{15} and r16−r18subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18r_{16}-r_{18} do not share any phone number or URL domain; the only “connector” between them is r13subscript𝑟13r_{13}, so they can be wrongly merged if r13subscript𝑟13r_{13} contains erroneous values. Also, considering r13−r15subscript𝑟13subscript𝑟15r_{13}-r_{15} and r16−r18subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18r_{16}-r_{18} as two different cores is risky, because (1) it is not very clear whether r13subscript𝑟13r_{13} is in the same chain as r14−r15subscript𝑟14subscript𝑟15r_{14}-r_{15} or as r16−r18subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18r_{16}-r_{18}, and (2) these two cores share one URL domain name so are not fully distinguishable.

We capture this intuition with connectivity of a similarity graph. We define the similarity graph of a set 𝐑𝐑\bf R of records as an undirected graph, where each node represents a record in R, and an edge indicates high similarity between the connected records (we describe later what we mean by high similarity). Figure 1 shows the similarity graph for the motivating example.

Each core would correspond to a connected sub-graph of the similarity graph. We wish such a sub-graph to be robust such that even if we remove a few nodes the sub-graph is still connected; in other words, even if there are some erroneous records, without them we still have enough evidence showing that the rest of the records should belong to the same group. The formal definition goes as follows.

Definition 4.1 (k𝑘k-robustness)

A graph G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust if after removing arbitrary k𝑘k nodes and edges to these nodes, G𝐺G is still connected. A clique or a single node is k𝑘k-robust for any k𝑘k. □□\Box

In Figure 1, the subgraph with nodes r1−r7subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟7r_{1}-r_{7} is 2-robust. That with r11−r18subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟18r_{11}-r_{18} is not 1-robust, as removing r13subscript𝑟13r_{13} can disconnect it.

According to the definition, we can partition the similarity graph into a set of k𝑘k-robust subgraphs. As we do not wish to split any core unnecessarily, we require the maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning:

Definition 4.2 (Maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning)

Let G𝐺G be a similarity graph. A partitioning of G𝐺G is a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning if it satisfies the following properties.

  1. 1.

    Each node belongs to one and only one partition.

  2. 2.

    Each partition is k𝑘k-robust.

  3. 3.

    The result of merging any partitions is not k𝑘k-robust. □□\Box

Note that a data set can have more than one maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning. Consider r11−r18subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟18r_{11}-r_{18} in Figure 1. There are three maximal 1-robust partitionings: {{r11},{r12,r14−r15},{r13,r16−r18}}subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟12subscript𝑟14subscript𝑟15subscript𝑟13subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18\{\{r_{11}\},\{r_{12},r_{14}-r_{15}\},\{r_{13},r_{16}-r_{18}\}\}; {{r11−r12},{r14−r15},{r13,r16−r18}}subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟12subscript𝑟14subscript𝑟15subscript𝑟13subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18\{\{r_{11}-r_{12}\},\{r_{14}-r_{15}\},\{r_{13},r_{16}-r_{18}\}\}; and {{r11−r15},{r16−r18}}subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟15subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18\{\{r_{11}-r_{15}\},\{r_{16}-r_{18}\}\}. If we treat each partitioning as a possible world, records that belong to the same partition in all possible worlds have high probability to belong to the same group and so form a core. Accordingly, we define a core as follows and can prove its k𝑘k-robustness.

Definition 4.3 (k𝑘k-Core)

Let 𝐑𝐑\bf R be a set of records and G𝐺G be the similarity graph of 𝐑𝐑\bf R. The records that belong to the same subgraph in every maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning of G𝐺G form a k𝑘k-core of 𝐑𝐑\bf R. A core contains at least 2 records. □□\Box

Property 4.4

A k𝑘k-core is k𝑘k-robust. □□\Box

Proof 4.1.

If a k𝑘k-core Crsubscript𝐶𝑟C_{r} of G𝐺G is not k𝑘k-robust, there exists a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning in G𝐺G, where two nodes r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} in Crsubscript𝐶𝑟C_{r} are in different partitions of this partitioning (proved by Lemma 4.21). This conflicts with the fact that records in Crsubscript𝐶𝑟C_{r} belong to the same partition in every maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning of G𝐺G. Therefore, a k𝑘k-core is k𝑘k-robust.

Example 4.2.

Consider Figure 1 and assume k=1𝑘1k=1. There are two connected sub-graphs. For records r1−r7subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟7r_{1}-r_{7}, the subgraph is 1-robust, so they form a 111-core. For records r11−r18subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟18r_{11}-r_{18}, there are three maximal 1-robust partitionings for the subgraph, as we have shown. Two subsets of records belong to the same subgraph in each partitioning: {r14−r15}subscript𝑟14subscript𝑟15\{r_{14}-r_{15}\} and {r16−r18}subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18\{r_{16}-r_{18}\}; they form 2 111-cores. □□\Box

4.2 Constructing similarity graphs

Generating the cores requires analysis on the similarity graph. Even after blocking, a block can contain tens of thousands of records, so it is not scalable to compare every pair of records in the same block and create edges accordingly. We next describe how we construct and represent the similarity graph in a scalable way.

We add an edge between two records if they have the same value for each common-value attribute and share at least one value on a dominant-value attribute222In practice, we require only highly similar values for common-value attributes and apply the transitive rule on similarity (i.e., if v1subscript𝑣1v_{1} and v2subscript𝑣2v_{2} are highly similar, and so are v2subscript𝑣2v_{2} and v3subscript𝑣3v_{3}, we consider v1subscript𝑣1v_{1} and v3subscript𝑣3v_{3} highly similar).; our experiments show advantages of this method over other edge-adding strategies (Section 6.2.1). All records that share values on the common-value attributes and share the same value on a dominant-value attribute form a clique, which we call a v-clique. We can thus represent the graph with a set of v-cliques, denoted by 𝐂𝐂\bf C; for example, the graph in Figure 1 can be represented by 5 v-cliques (C1−C5subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶5C_{1}-C_{5}). In addition, we maintain an inverted index L¯¯𝐿\bar{L}, where each entry corresponds to a record r𝑟r and contains the v-cliques that r𝑟r belongs to. Whereas the size of the similarity graph can be quadratic in the number of the nodes, the size of the inverted index is only linear in that number. The inverted index also makes it easy to find adjacent v-cliques (i.e., v-cliques that share nodes), as they appear in the same entry.

Graph construction is then reduced to v-clique finding, which can be done by scanning values of dominant-value attributes. In this process, we wish to prune a v-clique if it is a sub-clique of another one. Pruning by checking every pair of v-cliques can be very expensive since the number of v-cliques is also huge. Instead, we do it together with v-clique finding. Specifically, our algorithm GraphConstruction takes 𝐑𝐑\bf R as input and outputs 𝐂𝐂\bf C and L¯¯𝐿\bar{L}. We start with 𝐂=L¯=∅𝐂¯𝐿{\bf C}=\bar{L}=\emptyset. For each value v𝑣v of a dominant-value attribute, we denote the set of records with v𝑣v by R¯vsubscript¯𝑅𝑣\bar{R}_{v} and do the following.

  1. 1.

    Initialize the v-cliques for v𝑣v as 𝐂𝐯=∅subscript𝐂𝐯\bf C_{v}=\emptyset. Add a single-record cluster for each record r∈R¯v𝑟subscript¯𝑅𝑣r\in\bar{R}_{v} to a working set T¯¯𝑇\bar{T}. Mark each cluster as “unchanged”.

  2. 2.

    For each r∈R¯v𝑟subscript¯𝑅𝑣r\in\bar{R}_{v}, scan L¯¯𝐿\bar{L} and consider each v-clique C∈L¯​(r)𝐶¯𝐿𝑟C\in\bar{L}(r) that has not been considered yet. For all records in C∩Rv𝐶subscript𝑅𝑣C\cap R_{v}, merge their clusters. Mark the merged cluster as “changed” if the result is not a proper sub-clique of C¯¯𝐶\bar{C}. If C⊆R¯v𝐶subscript¯𝑅𝑣C\subseteq\bar{R}_{v}, remove C𝐶C from 𝐂𝐂\bf C. This step removes the v-cliques that must be sub-cliques of those we will form next.

  3. 3.

    For each cluster C∈T¯𝐶¯𝑇C\in\bar{T}, if there exists C′∈𝐂𝐯superscript𝐶′subscript𝐂𝐯C^{\prime}\in\bf C_{v} such that C𝐶C and C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} share the same value for each common-value attribute, remove C𝐶C and C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} from T¯¯𝑇\bar{T} and 𝐂𝐯subscript𝐂𝐯\bf C_{v} respectively, add C∪C′𝐶superscript𝐶′C\cup C^{\prime} to T¯¯𝑇\bar{T} and mark it as “changed”; otherwise, move C𝐶C to 𝐂𝐯subscript𝐂𝐯\bf C_{v}. This step merges clusters that share values on common-value attributes. At the end, 𝐂𝐯subscript𝐂𝐯\bf C_{v} contains the v-cliques with value v𝑣v.

  4. 4.

    Add each v-clique with mark “changed” in 𝐂𝐯subscript𝐂𝐯\bf C_{v} to 𝐂𝐂\bf C and update L¯¯𝐿\bar{L} accordingly. The marking prunes size-1 v-cliques and the sub-cliques of those already in 𝐂𝐂\bf C.

Proposition 4.3.

Let 𝐑𝐑\bf R be a set of records. Denote by n​(r)𝑛𝑟n(r) the number of values on dominant-value attributes from r∈𝐑𝑟𝐑r\in\bf R. Let n=∑r∈𝐑n​(r)𝑛subscript𝑟𝐑𝑛𝑟n=\sum_{r\in\bf R}n(r) and m=maxr∈𝐑⁡n​(r)𝑚subscript𝑟𝐑𝑛𝑟m=\max_{r\in\bf R}n(r). Let s𝑠s be the maximum v-clique size. Algorithm GraphConstruction (1) runs in time O​(n​s​(m+s))𝑂𝑛𝑠𝑚𝑠O(ns(m+s)), (2) requires space O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n), and (3) its result is independent of the order in which we consider the records. □□\Box

Proof 4.4.

We first prove that GraphConstruction runs in time O​(n​s​(m+s))𝑂𝑛𝑠𝑚𝑠O(ns(m+s)). Step 2 of the algorithm takes in time O​(n​s​m)𝑂𝑛𝑠𝑚O(nsm), where it takes in time O​(n​s)𝑂𝑛𝑠O(ns) to scan all records for a dominant-value attribute, and a record can be scanned maximally m𝑚m times. Step 3 takes in time O​(n​s2)𝑂𝑛superscript𝑠2O(ns^{2}). Thus, the algorithm runs in time O​(n​s​(m+s))𝑂𝑛𝑠𝑚𝑠O(ns(m+s)).

We next prove that GraphConstruction requires space O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n). For each value v𝑣v of a dominate-value attribute, the algorithm keeps three data sets: L¯¯𝐿\bar{L} that takes in space O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n), 𝐂𝐯subscript𝐂𝐯\bf C_{v} and T¯¯𝑇\bar{T} that require space in total no greater than O​(|𝐑|)𝑂𝐑O(\bf|R|). Since O​(n)≥O​(|𝐑|)𝑂𝑛𝑂𝐑O(n)\geq O(\bf|R|), the algorithm requires space O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n).

We now prove that the result of GraphConstruction is order independent. Given L¯¯𝐿\bar{L} and R¯vsubscript¯𝑅𝑣\bar{R}_{v}, Step 2 scan L¯¯𝐿\bar{L} and apply transitive rule to merge clusters of records in C∩R¯v𝐶subscript¯𝑅𝑣C\cap\bar{R}_{v}, for each v-clique C∈L¯𝐶¯𝐿C\in\bar{L}. The process is independent from the order in which we consider the records in R¯vsubscript¯𝑅𝑣\bar{R}_{v}. The order independence of the result in Step 3 is proven in [2]. Therefore, the final result is independent from the order in which we consider the records.

Example 4.5.

Consider graph construction for records in Table 2. Figure1 shows the similarity graph and Table 3(a) shows the inverted list. We focus on records r1−r8subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟8r_{1}-r_{8} for illustration.

First, r1−r5subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟5r_{1}-r_{5} share the same name and phone number 808, so we add v-clique C1={r1−r5}subscript𝐶1subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟5C_{1}=\{r_{1}-r_{5}\} to 𝐂𝐂\bf C. Now consider URL homedepot where R¯v={r3−r8}subscript¯𝑅𝑣subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟8\bar{R}_{v}=\{r_{3}-r_{8}\}. Step 1 generates 6 clusters, each marked “unchanged”, and T¯={{r3},…,{r8}}¯𝑇subscript𝑟3…subscript𝑟8\bar{T}=\{\{r_{3}\},\dots,\{r_{8}\}\}. Step 2 looks up L¯¯𝐿\bar{L} for each record in R¯vsubscript¯𝑅𝑣\bar{R}_{v}. Among them, r3−r5subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟5r_{3}-r_{5} belong to v-clique C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}, so it merges their clusters and marks the result {r3−r5}subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟5\{r_{3}-r_{5}\} “unchanged” ({r3−r5}⊂C1subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟5subscript𝐶1\{r_{3}-r_{5}\}\subset C_{1}); then, T¯={{r3−r5},{r6},{r7},{r8}}¯𝑇subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟5subscript𝑟6subscript𝑟7subscript𝑟8\bar{T}=\{\{r_{3}-r_{5}\},\{r_{6}\},\{r_{7}\},\{r_{8}\}\}. Step 3 compares these clusters and merges the first three as they share the same name, marking the result as “changed”. At the end, 𝐂v={{r3−r7},{r8}}subscript𝐂𝑣subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟7subscript𝑟8{\bf C}_{v}=\{\{r_{3}-r_{7}\},\{r_{8}\}\}. Finally, Step 4 adds {r3−r7}subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟7\{r_{3}-r_{7}\} to 𝐂𝐂\bf C and discards {r8}subscript𝑟8\{r_{8}\} since it is marked “unchanged”. □□\Box

Given the sheer number of records in 𝐑𝐑\bf R, the inverted index can still be huge. In fact, according to the following theorem, records in the same v-clique but not any other v-clique must belong to the same core, so we do not need to distinguish them. Thus, we simplify the inverted index such that for each v-clique we keep only a representative for nodes belonging only to this v-clique. Table 3 shows the simplified index for the similarity graph in Figure 1.

Theorem 4.5.

Let G𝐺G be a similarity graph and G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} be a graph derived from G𝐺G by merging nodes that belong to only one and the same v𝑣v-clique. Two nodes belong to the same core of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} if and only if they belong to the same core of G𝐺G. □□\Box

Proof 4.6.

We need to prove that (1) if two nodes r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} belong to the same core in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}, they are in the same core of G𝐺G, and (2) if two nodes r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} belong to the same core of G𝐺G, they are in the same core of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}.

We first prove that if two nodes r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} belong to the same core in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}, they are in the same core of G𝐺G. Suppose there does not exist any core in G𝐺G that contains both r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}. It means that there exists a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning in G𝐺G, where r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are in different partitions. Let P𝑃P be such a partitioning of G𝐺G and we consider partitioning P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}, where each pair of nodes in the same partition C𝐶C of P𝑃P are in the same partition C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} of P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} and vice versa. We prove that P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} is a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}. (1) It is obvious that each node in P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} belongs to one and only one partition. (2) For each partition C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} in P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime}, removing any k𝑘k nodes in C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} is equivalent to removing n+m𝑛𝑚n+m nodes in C𝐶C, where n𝑛n nodes belong to more than one v𝑣v-cliques in C𝐶C, m𝑚m nodes belong to single v𝑣v-cliques in C𝐶C, and n≤k𝑛𝑘n\leq k. Since removing m𝑚m nodes that belong to single v𝑣v-cliques do not disconnect C𝐶C and we know n≤k𝑛𝑘n\leq k, removing the n+m𝑛𝑚n+m nodes does not disconnect C𝐶C. It in turn proves that removing k𝑘k nodes in C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} does not disconnect C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}, and C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} is k𝑘k-robust. (3) Similarly, we have that the result of of merging any partitions in P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} is not k𝑘k-robust. Therefore, P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} is a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}. Given that r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are in different partitions of P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime}, there does not exist a core of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} that contains both r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}. This conflicts with the fact that r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} belong to the same core in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}, and further proves that r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are in the same core of G𝐺G.

We next prove that if two nodes r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} belong to the same core of G𝐺G, they are in the same core of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}. Suppose there does not exist any core in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} that contains both r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}. It means that there exists a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}, where r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are in different partitions. Let P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} be such a partitioning of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} and we consider partitioning P𝑃P of G𝐺G, where each pair of nodes in the same partition C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} of P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} are in the same partition C𝐶C of P𝑃P and vice versa. In similar ways as above, we have that P𝑃P is a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning in G𝐺G. Given that r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are in different partitions of P𝑃P, there does not exist a core of G𝐺G that contains both r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}. This conflicts with the fact that r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} belong to the same core in G𝐺G, and further proves that r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are in the same core of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}.

Case study: On a data set with 18M records (described in Section 6), our graph-construction algorithm finished in 1.9 hours. The original similarity graph contains 18M nodes and 4.2B edges. The inverted index is of size 89MB, containing 3.8M entries, each associated with at most 8 v-cliques; in total there are 1.2M v-cliques. The simplified inverted index is of size 34MB, containing 1.5M entries, where an entry can represent up to 11K records. Therefore, the simplified inverted index reduces the size of the similarity graph by 3 orders of magnitude.

4.3 Identifying cores

We solve the core-identification problem by reducing it to a Max-flow/Min-cut Problem. However, computing the max flow for a given graph G𝐺G and a source-destination pair takes time O​(|G|2.5)𝑂superscript𝐺2.5O(|G|^{2.5}), where |G|𝐺|G| denotes the number of nodes in G𝐺G; even the simplified inverted index can still contain millions of entries, so it can be very expensive. We thus first merge certain v-cliques according to a sufficient (but not necessary) condition for k𝑘k-robustness and consider them as a whole in core identification; we then split the graph into subgraphs according to a necessary (but not sufficient) condition for k𝑘k-robustness. We apply reduction only on the resulting subgraphs, which are substantially smaller as we show at the end of this section. Section 4.3.1 describes screening before reduction, Section 4.3.2 describes the reduction, and Section 4.3.3 gives the full algorithm, which iteratively applies screening and the reduction.

4.3.1 Screening

A graph can be considered as a union of v-cliques, so essentially we need to decide if a union of v-cliques is k𝑘k-robust. First, we can prove the following sufficient condition for k𝑘k-robustness.

Theorem 4.6 ((K+1)𝐾1(K+1)-connected condition).

Let G𝐺G be a graph consisting of a union Q𝑄Q of v-cliques. If for every pair of v-cliques C,C′∈Q𝐶superscript𝐶′𝑄C,C^{\prime}\in Q, there is a path of v-cliques between C𝐶C and C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} and every pair of adjacent v-cliques on the path share at least k+1𝑘1k+1 nodes, graph G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust. □□\Box

Proof 4.7.

Given Menger’s Theorem [3], graph G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust if for any pair of nodes r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} in G𝐺G, there exists at least k+1𝑘1k+1 independent paths that do not share any nodes other than r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} in G𝐺G. We now prove that for any pair of nodes r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} in graph G𝐺G that satisfies (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected condition, there exists at least k+1𝑘1k+1 independent paths between r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime}. We consider two cases, 1) r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} are adjacent such that there exists a v-clique in G𝐺G that contains r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime}; 2) r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} are not adjacent such that there exists no v-clique in G𝐺G that contains r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime}.

We first consider Case 1 where there exists a v-clique C𝐶C containing r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime}. Since each v-clique in G𝐺G has more than k+1𝑘1k+1 nodes, there exist at least k𝑘k 2-length paths and one 1-length path between r,r′∈C𝑟superscript𝑟′𝐶r,r^{\prime}\in C. It proves that there exists at least k+1𝑘1k+1 independent paths between r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}.

We next consider Case 2 where there exists no v-clique containing r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} in G𝐺G. Suppose r∈C,r′∈C′formulae-sequence𝑟𝐶superscript𝑟′superscript𝐶′r\in C,r^{\prime}\in C^{\prime}, where C,C′𝐶superscript𝐶′C,C^{\prime} are different v-cliques in G𝐺G. Since there exists a path of v-cliques between C𝐶C and C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} where every pair of adjacent v-cliques in the path share at least k+1𝑘1k+1 nodes, there exists at least k+1𝑘1k+1 independent paths between r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}.

Given the above two cases, we have that there exist at least k+1𝑘1k+1 independent paths between every pair of nodes in G𝐺G, therefore G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust.

We call a single v-clique or a union of v-cliques that satisfy the (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected condition a (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-union. A (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-union must be k𝑘k-robust but not vice versa. In Figure 1, subgraph {r1−r7}subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟7\{r_{1}-r_{7}\} is a 3-connected v-union, because the only two v-cliques, C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}, share 3 nodes. Indeed, it is 2-robust. On the other hand, graph G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} in Figure 2 is 2-robust but not 3-connected (there are 4 v-cliques, where each pair of adjacent v-cliques share only 1 or 2 nodes). Accordingly, we can consider a v-union as a whole in core identification.

Next, we present a necessary condition for k𝑘k-robustness.

Theorem 4.7 ((K+1)𝐾1(K+1)-overlap condition).

Graph G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust only if for every (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-union Q∈G𝑄𝐺Q\in G, Q𝑄Q shares at least k+1𝑘1k+1 common nodes with the subgraph consisting of the rest of the v-unions. □□\Box

Proof 4.8.

We prove that if graph G𝐺G contains a (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-union Q𝑄Q that shares at most k𝑘k common nodes with the rest of the graph, G𝐺G is not k𝑘k-robust. Since Q𝑄Q shares at most k𝑘k common nodes with the subgraph consisting of the rest of the v-unions, removing the common nodes will disconnect Q𝑄Q from G𝐺G, it proves that G𝐺G is not k𝑘k-robust. Thus, (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap condition holds.

We call a graph G𝐺G that satisfies the (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap condition a (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap graph. A k𝑘k-robust graph must be a (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap graph but not vice versa. In Figure 1, subgraph {r11−r18}subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟18\{r_{11}-r_{18}\} is not a 2-overlap graph, because there are two 2-connected v-unions, {r11−r15}subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟15\{r_{11}-r_{15}\} and {r13,r16−r18}subscript𝑟13subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18\{r_{13},r_{16}-r_{18}\}, but they share only one node; indeed, the subgraph is not 1-robust. On the other hand, graph G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} in Figure 2 satisfies the 3-overlap condition, as it contains four 3-connected v-unions (actually four v-cliques), Q1−Q4subscript𝑄1subscript𝑄4Q_{1}-Q_{4}, and each v-union shares 3 nodes in total with the others; however, it is not 2-robust (removing r3subscript𝑟3r_{3} and r4subscript𝑟4r_{4} disconnects it). Accordingly, for (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap graphs we still need to check k𝑘k-robustness by reduction to a Max-flow Problem.

Now the problem is to find (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap subgraphs. Let G𝐺G be a graph where a (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-union overlaps with the rest of the v-unions on no more than k𝑘k nodes. We split G𝐺G by removing these overlapping nodes. For subgraph {r11−r18}subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟18\{r_{11}-r_{18}\} in Figure 1, we remove r13subscript𝑟13r_{13} and obtain two subgraphs {r11−r12,r14−r15}subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟12subscript𝑟14subscript𝑟15\{r_{11}-r_{12},r_{14}-r_{15}\} and {r16−r18}subscript𝑟16subscript𝑟18\{r_{16}-r_{18}\} (recall from Example 4.2 that r13subscript𝑟13r_{13} cannot belong to any core). Note that the result subgraphs may not be (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap graphs (e.g., {r11−r12,r14−r15}subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟12subscript𝑟14subscript𝑟15\{r_{11}-r_{12},r_{14}-r_{15}\} contains two v-unions that share only one node), so we need to further screen them.

We now describe our screening algorithm, Screen (details in Algorithm 1), which takes a graph G𝐺G, represented by 𝐂𝐂\bf C and L¯¯𝐿\bar{L}, as input, finds (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions in G𝐺G and meanwhile decides if G𝐺G is a (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap graph. If not, it splits G𝐺G into subgraphs for further examination.

  1. 1.

    If G𝐺G contains a single node, output it as a core if the node represents multiple records that belong only to one v-clique.

  2. 2.

    For each v-clique C∈𝐂𝐶𝐂C\in\bf C, initialize a v-union. We denote the set of v-unions by Q¯¯𝑄\bar{Q}, the v-union that C𝐶C belongs to by Q​(C)𝑄𝐶Q(C), and the overlapping nodes of C𝐶C and C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} by B¯​(C,C′)¯𝐵𝐶superscript𝐶′\bar{B}(C,C^{\prime}).

  3. 3.

    For each v-clique C∈𝐂𝐶𝐂C\in\bf C, we merge v-unions as follows.

    (a) For each record r∈C𝑟𝐶r\in C that has not been considered, for every pair of v-cliques C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} in r𝑟r’s index entry, if they belong to different v-unions, add r𝑟r to overlap B¯​(C1,C2)¯𝐵subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2\bar{B}(C_{1},C_{2}).

    (b) For each v-union Q≠Q​(C)𝑄𝑄𝐶Q\neq Q(C) where there exist C1∈Qsubscript𝐶1𝑄C_{1}\in Q and C2∈Q​(C)subscript𝐶2𝑄𝐶C_{2}\in Q(C) such that |B¯​(C1,C2)|≥k+1¯𝐵subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2𝑘1|\bar{B}(C_{1},C_{2})|\geq k+1, merge Q𝑄Q and Q​(C)𝑄𝐶Q(C).

    At the end, Q¯¯𝑄\bar{Q} contains all (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions.

  4. 4.

    For each v-union Q∈Q¯𝑄¯𝑄Q\in\bar{Q}, find its border nodes as B¯​(Q)=∪C∈Q,C′∉QB¯​(C,C′)¯𝐵𝑄subscriptformulae-sequence𝐶𝑄superscript𝐶′𝑄¯𝐵𝐶superscript𝐶′\bar{B}(Q)=\cup_{C\in Q,C^{\prime}\not\in Q}\bar{B}(C,C^{\prime}). If |B¯​(Q)|≤k¯𝐵𝑄𝑘|\bar{B}(Q)|\leq k, split the subgraph it belongs to, denoted by G​(Q)𝐺𝑄G(Q), into two subgraphs Q∖B¯​(Q)𝑄¯𝐵𝑄Q\setminus\bar{B}(Q) and G​(Q)∖Q𝐺𝑄𝑄G(Q)\setminus Q.

  5. 5.

    Return the remaining subgraphs.

Proposition 4.9.

Denote by |L¯|¯𝐿|\bar{L}| the number of entries in input L¯¯𝐿\bar{L}. Let m𝑚m be the maximum number of values from dominant-value attributes of a record, and a𝑎a be the maximum number of adjacent v-unions that a v-union has. Algorithm Screen finds (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap subgraphs in time O​((m2+a)⋅|L¯|)𝑂⋅superscript𝑚2𝑎¯𝐿O((m^{2}+a)\cdot|\bar{L}|) and the result is independent of the order in which we examine the v-cliques. □□\Box

Proof 4.10.

We first prove the time complexity of Screen. It takes in time O​(m2​|L¯|)𝑂superscript𝑚2¯𝐿O(m^{2}|\bar{L}|) to scan all entries in L¯¯𝐿\bar{L} and find common nodes between each pair of adjacent v-cliques (Step 3(a)). It takes in time O​(a​|𝐂|)𝑂𝑎𝐂O(a|\bf C|) to merge v-unions, where |𝐂|𝐂|\bf C| is the number of v-cliques in G𝐺G (Step 3(b)). Since |𝐂|𝐂|\bf C| <|L¯|absent¯𝐿<|\bar{L}|, the algorithm runs in time O​(m2+a)⋅|L¯|⋅𝑂superscript𝑚2𝑎¯𝐿O(m^{2}+a)\cdot|\bar{L}|.

We next prove that the result of ScreenScreen\sc Screen is independent of the order in which we examine the v-cliques, that is, 1) finding all maximal (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions in G𝐺G is order independent; 2) removing all nodes in B¯​(Q)¯𝐵𝑄\bar{B}(Q) from G𝐺G where |B¯​(Q)|≤k¯𝐵𝑄𝑘|\bar{B}(Q)|\leq k is order independent.

Consider order independency of finding all v-unions in G𝐺G. To find all v-unions in G𝐺G is conceptually equivalent to find all connected components in an abstract graph GAsubscript𝐺𝐴G_{A}, where each node in GAsubscript𝐺𝐴G_{A} is a v-clique in G𝐺G and two nodes in GAsubscript𝐺𝐴G_{A} are connected if the two corresponding v-cliques share more than k𝑘k nodes. Screen checks whether each node in G𝐺G is a common node between two v-cliques (Step 3(a)), and if two cliques share more than k𝑘k nodes, merges their v-unions (Step 3(b)), which is equivalent to connect two nodes in GAsubscript𝐺𝐴G_{A}. Once all nodes in G𝐺G is scanned, all edges in GAsubscript𝐺𝐴G_{A} are added, and the order in which we examine nodes in G𝐺G is independent from the structure of GAsubscript𝐺𝐴G_{A} and the connected components in GAsubscript𝐺𝐴G_{A}. Therefore, finding all v-unions in G𝐺G is order independent.

Consider order independency of removing nodes in G𝐺G. Suppose Q1,Q2,…,Qm,m>0subscript𝑄1subscript𝑄2…subscript𝑄𝑚𝑚0Q_{1},Q_{2},...,Q_{m},m>0 are all v-unions in G𝐺G with |B¯​(Qi)|≤k,i∈[1,m]formulae-sequence¯𝐵subscript𝑄𝑖𝑘𝑖1𝑚|\bar{B}(Q_{i})|\leq k,i\in[1,m]. Since G𝐺G is finite, Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} is finite and unique; thus, removing all nodes in B¯(Q))\bar{B}(Q)) from G𝐺G where |B¯​(Q)|≤k¯𝐵𝑄𝑘|\bar{B}(Q)|\leq k is order independent.

Note that m𝑚m and a𝑎a are typically very small, so Screen is basically linear in the size of the inverted index. Finally, we have results similar to Theorem 4.5 for v-unions, so we can further simplify the graph by keeping for each v-union a single representative for all nodes that only belong to it. Each result k𝑘k-overlap subgraph is typically very small.

Example 4.11.

Consider Table 3 as input and k=1𝑘1k=1. Step 2 creates five v-unions Q1−Q5subscript𝑄1subscript𝑄5Q_{1}-Q_{5} for the five v-cliques in the input.

Step 3 starts with v-clique C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}. It has 4 nodes (in the simplified inverted index), among which 3 are shared with C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}. Thus, B¯​(C1,C2)={r3−r5}¯𝐵subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟5\bar{B}(C_{1},C_{2})=\{r_{3}-r_{5}\} and |B¯​(C1,C2)|≥2¯𝐵subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶22|\bar{B}(C_{1},C_{2})|\geq 2, so we merge Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} and Q2subscript𝑄2Q_{2} into Q1/2subscript𝑄12Q_{1/2}. Examining C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} reveals no other shared node.

Step 3 then considers v-clique C3subscript𝐶3C_{3}. It has three nodes, among which r12−r13subscript𝑟12subscript𝑟13r_{12}-r_{13} are shared with C4subscript𝐶4C_{4} and r13subscript𝑟13r_{13} is also shared with C5subscript𝐶5C_{5}. Thus, B¯​(C3,C4)={r12−r13}¯𝐵subscript𝐶3subscript𝐶4subscript𝑟12subscript𝑟13\bar{B}(C_{3},C_{4})=\{r_{12}-r_{13}\} and B¯​(C3,C5)={r13}¯𝐵subscript𝐶3subscript𝐶5subscript𝑟13\bar{B}(C_{3},C_{5})=\{r_{13}\}. We merge Q3subscript𝑄3Q_{3} and Q4subscript𝑄4Q_{4} into Q3/4subscript𝑄34Q_{3/4}. Examining C4subscript𝐶4C_{4} and C5subscript𝐶5C_{5} reveals no other shared node. We thus obtain three 2-connected v-unions: Q¯={Q1/2,Q3/4,Q5}¯𝑄subscript𝑄12subscript𝑄34subscript𝑄5\bar{Q}=\{Q_{1/2},Q_{3/4},Q_{5}\}.

Step 4 then considers each v-union. For Q1/2subscript𝑄12Q_{1/2}, B¯​(Q1/2)=∅¯𝐵subscript𝑄12\bar{B}(Q_{1/2})=\emptyset and we thus split subgraph Q1/2subscript𝑄12Q_{1/2} out and merge all of its nodes to one r1/⋯/7subscript𝑟1⋯7r_{1/\dots/7}. For Q3/4subscript𝑄34Q_{3/4}, B¯​(Q3/4)={r13}¯𝐵subscript𝑄34subscript𝑟13\bar{B}(Q_{3/4})=\{r_{13}\} so |B¯​(Q3/4)|<2¯𝐵subscript𝑄342|\bar{B}(Q_{3/4})|<2. We split Q3/4subscript𝑄34Q_{3/4} out and obtain {r11−r12,r14/15}subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟12subscript𝑟1415\{r_{11}-r_{12},r_{14/15}\} (r13subscript𝑟13r_{13} is excluded). Similar for Q5subscript𝑄5Q_{5} and we obtain {r16/17/18}subscript𝑟161718\{r_{16/17/18}\}. Therefore, we return three subgraphs for further screening. □□\Box

4.3.2 Reduction

Intuitively, a graph G​(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G(V,E) is k𝑘k-robust if and only if between any two nodes a,b∈V𝑎𝑏𝑉a,b\in V, there are more than k𝑘k paths that do not share any node except a𝑎a and b𝑏b. We denote the number of non-overlapping paths between nodes a𝑎a and b𝑏b by κ​(a,b)𝜅𝑎𝑏\kappa(a,b). We can reduce the problem of computing κ​(a,b)𝜅𝑎𝑏\kappa(a,b) into a Max-flow Problem.

For each input G​(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G(V,E) and nodes a,b𝑎𝑏a,b, we construct the (directed) flow network G′​(V′,E′)superscript𝐺′superscript𝑉′superscript𝐸′G^{\prime}(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}) as follows.

  1. 1.

    Node a𝑎a is the source and b𝑏b is the sink (there is no particular order between a𝑎a and b𝑏b).

  2. 2.

    For each v∈V,v≠a,v≠bformulae-sequence𝑣𝑉formulae-sequence𝑣𝑎𝑣𝑏v\in V,v\neq a,v\neq b, add two nodes v′,v′′superscript𝑣′superscript𝑣′′v^{\prime},v^{\prime\prime} to V′superscript𝑉′V^{\prime}, and two directed edges (v′,v′′),(v′′,v′)superscript𝑣′superscript𝑣′′superscript𝑣′′superscript𝑣′(v^{\prime},v^{\prime\prime}),(v^{\prime\prime},v^{\prime}) to E′superscript𝐸′E^{\prime}. If v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime} represents n𝑛n nodes, the edge (v′,v′′)superscript𝑣′superscript𝑣′′(v^{\prime},v^{\prime\prime}) has weight n𝑛n, and the edge (v′′,v′)superscript𝑣′′superscript𝑣′(v^{\prime\prime},v^{\prime}) has weight ∞\infty.

  3. 3.

    For each edge (a,v)∈E𝑎𝑣𝐸(a,v)\in E, add edge (a,v′)𝑎superscript𝑣′(a,v^{\prime}) to E′superscript𝐸′E^{\prime}; for each edge (u,b)∈E𝑢𝑏𝐸(u,b)\in E, add edge (u′′,b)superscript𝑢′′𝑏(u^{\prime\prime},b) to E′superscript𝐸′E^{\prime}; for each other edge (u,v)∈E𝑢𝑣𝐸(u,v)\in E, add two edges (u′′,v′)superscript𝑢′′superscript𝑣′(u^{\prime\prime},v^{\prime}) and (v′′,u′)superscript𝑣′′superscript𝑢′(v^{\prime\prime},u^{\prime}) to E′superscript𝐸′E^{\prime}. Each edge has capacity ∞\infty.

Lemma 4.12.

The max flow from source a𝑎a to sink b𝑏b in G′​(V′,E′)superscript𝐺′superscript𝑉′superscript𝐸′G^{\prime}(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}) is equivalent to κ​(a,b)𝜅𝑎𝑏\kappa(a,b) in G​(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G(V,E). □□\Box

Proof 4.13.

According to Menger’s Theorem [3], the minimum number of nodes whose removal disconnects a𝑎a and b𝑏b, that is κ​(a,b)𝜅𝑎𝑏\kappa(a,b), is equal to the maximum number of independent paths between a𝑎a and b𝑏b. The authors in [9] proves that the maximum number of independent paths between a𝑎a and b𝑏b in an undirected graph G​(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G(V,E) is equivalent to the maximal value of flow from a𝑎a to b𝑏b or the minimal capacity of an a−b𝑎𝑏a-b cut, the set of nodes such that any path from a𝑎a to b𝑏b contains a member of the cut, in G′​(V′,E′)superscript𝐺′superscript𝑉′superscript𝐸′G^{\prime}(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}).

Example 4.14.

Consider nodes r1subscript𝑟1r_{1} and r6subscript𝑟6r_{6} of graph G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} in Figure 2. Figure 3 shows the corresponding flow network, where the dash line (across edges (r3′,r3′′),(r4′,r4′′)superscriptsubscript𝑟3′superscriptsubscript𝑟3′′superscriptsubscript𝑟4′superscriptsubscript𝑟4′′(r_{3}^{\prime},r_{3}^{\prime\prime}),(r_{4}^{\prime},r_{4}^{\prime\prime})) in the figure cuts the flow from r1subscript𝑟1r_{1} to r6subscript𝑟6r_{6} with a minimum cost of 2. The max flow/min cut has value 2. Indeed, κ​(r1,r6)=2𝜅subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟62\kappa(r_{1},r_{6})=2. □□\Box

Recall that in a (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-union, between each pair of nodes there are at least k+1𝑘1k+1 paths. Thus, if (1) κ​(a,b)=k+1𝜅𝑎𝑏𝑘1\kappa(a,b)=k+1, (2) a𝑎a and b𝑏b belong to different v-unions, and (3) a𝑎a and a′superscript𝑎′a^{\prime} belong to the same v-union, we must have κ​(a′,b)≥k+1𝜅superscript𝑎′𝑏𝑘1\kappa(a^{\prime},b)\geq k+1. We thus have the following sufficient and necessary condition for k𝑘k-robustness.

Theorem 4.14 (Max-flow condition).

Let G​(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G(V,E) be an input similarity graph. Graph G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust if and only if for every pair of adjacent (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions Q𝑄Q and Q′superscript𝑄′Q^{\prime}, there exist two nodes a∈Q∖Q′𝑎𝑄superscript𝑄′a\in Q\setminus Q^{\prime} and b∈Q′∖Q𝑏superscript𝑄′𝑄b\in Q^{\prime}\setminus Q such that the max flow from a𝑎a to b𝑏b in the corresponding flow network is at least k+1𝑘1k+1. □□\Box

Proof 4.15.

According to Menger’s Theorem [3], κ​(a,b)𝜅𝑎𝑏\kappa(a,b) in G𝐺G is equivalent to the max-flow from a𝑎a to b𝑏b in the corresponding flow network. We need to prove that graph G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust if and only if for each pair of adjacent (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions Q𝑄Q and Q′superscript𝑄′Q^{\prime}, there exists two nodes a∈Q∖Q′𝑎𝑄superscript𝑄′a\in Q\setminus Q^{\prime} and b∈Q′∖Q𝑏superscript𝑄′𝑄b\in Q^{\prime}\setminus Q such that κ​(a,b)≥k+1𝜅𝑎𝑏𝑘1\kappa(a,b)\geq k+1.

We first prove that if G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust, for each pair of adjacent (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions Q𝑄Q and Q′superscript𝑄′Q^{\prime}, there exists two nodes a∈Q∖Q′𝑎𝑄superscript𝑄′a\in Q\setminus Q^{\prime} and b∈Q′∖Q𝑏superscript𝑄′𝑄b\in Q^{\prime}\setminus Q such that κ​(a,b)≥k+1𝜅𝑎𝑏𝑘1\kappa(a,b)\geq k+1. Since G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust, for each pair of nodes a𝑎a and b𝑏b in G𝐺G, we have κ​(a,b)≥k+1𝜅𝑎𝑏𝑘1\kappa(a,b)\geq k+1.

We next prove that if G𝐺G is not k𝑘k-robust, there exists a pair of adjacent (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions Q𝑄Q and Q′superscript𝑄′Q^{\prime} such that for each pair of nodes a∈Q∖Q′𝑎𝑄superscript𝑄′a\in Q\setminus Q^{\prime} and b∈Q′∖Q𝑏superscript𝑄′𝑄b\in Q^{\prime}\setminus Q, we have κ​(a,b)<k+1𝜅𝑎𝑏𝑘1\kappa(a,b)<k+1. Since G𝐺G is not k𝑘k-robust, there exists a separator S¯¯𝑆\bar{S}, a set of nodes in G𝐺G with size no greater than k𝑘k whose removal disconnects G𝐺G into two sub-graphs X¯¯𝑋\bar{X} and Y¯¯𝑌\bar{Y}. Suppose Q𝑄Q and Q′superscript𝑄′Q^{\prime} are two v-unions in G𝐺G such that Q⊆X¯,Q′⊆Y¯formulae-sequence𝑄¯𝑋superscript𝑄′¯𝑌Q\subseteq\bar{X},Q^{\prime}\subseteq\bar{Y} and Q∩Q′≠∅𝑄superscript𝑄′Q\cap Q^{\prime}\neq\emptyset. For each pair of nodes a∈Q∖Q′𝑎𝑄superscript𝑄′a\in Q\setminus Q^{\prime} and b∈Q′∖Q𝑏superscript𝑄′𝑄b\in Q^{\prime}\setminus Q, we have a∈X¯𝑎¯𝑋a\in\bar{X} and b∈Y¯𝑏¯𝑌b\in\bar{Y}, and removing the set of nodes in S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} disconnects a𝑎a and b𝑏b; thus κ​(a,b)<k+1𝜅𝑎𝑏𝑘1\kappa(a,b)<k+1.

The above two cases proves that graph G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust if and only if for every pair of adjacent (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions Q𝑄Q and Q′superscript𝑄′Q^{\prime}, there exist two nodes a∈Q∖Q′𝑎𝑄superscript𝑄′a\in Q\setminus Q^{\prime} and b∈Q′∖Q𝑏superscript𝑄′𝑄b\in Q^{\prime}\setminus Q such that κ​(a,b)≥k+1𝜅𝑎𝑏𝑘1\kappa(a,b)\geq k+1, i.e. the max flow from a𝑎a to b𝑏b in the corresponding flow network is at least k+1𝑘1k+1.

If a graph G𝐺G is not k𝑘k-robust, we shall split it into subgraphs for further processing. In the corresponding flow network, each edge in the minimum cut must be between a pair of nodes derived from the same node in G𝐺G (other edges have capacity ∞\infty). These nodes cannot belong to any core and we use them as separator nodes, denoted by S¯¯𝑆\bar{S}. Suppose the separator separates G𝐺G into X¯¯𝑋\bar{X} and Y¯¯𝑌\bar{Y} (there can be more subgraphs); we return X¯∪S¯¯𝑋¯𝑆\bar{X}\cup\bar{S} and Y¯∪S¯¯𝑌¯𝑆\bar{Y}\cup\bar{S}.

Note that we need to include S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} in both sub-graphs to maintain the integrity of each v-union. To understand why, consider G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} in Figure 2 where S¯={r3,r4}¯𝑆subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟4\bar{S}=\{r_{3},r_{4}\}. According to the definition, there is no 2-core. If we split G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} into {r1−r2}subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2\{r_{1}-r_{2}\} and {r5−r6}subscript𝑟5subscript𝑟6\{r_{5}-r_{6}\} (without including S¯¯𝑆\bar{S}), both subgraphs are 2-robust and we would return them as 2-cores. The problem happens because v-cliques Q1−Q4subscript𝑄1subscript𝑄4Q_{1}-Q_{4} “disappear” after we remove the separators r3subscript𝑟3r_{3} and r4subscript𝑟4r_{4}. Thus, we should split G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} into {r1−r4}subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟4\{r_{1}-r_{4}\} and {r3−r6}subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟6\{r_{3}-r_{6}\} instead and that would further trigger splitting on both subgraphs. Eventually we wish to exclude the separator nodes from any core, so we mark them as “separators” and exclude them from the returned cores.

Algorithm Split (details in Algorithm 2) takes a (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap subgraph G𝐺G as input and decides if G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust. If not, it splits G𝐺G into subgraphs on which we will then re-apply screening.

  1. 1.

    For each pair of adjacent (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions Q,Q′∈G𝑄superscript𝑄′𝐺Q,Q^{\prime}\in G, find a∈Q∖Q′,b∈Q′∖Qformulae-sequence𝑎𝑄superscript𝑄′𝑏superscript𝑄′𝑄a\in Q\setminus Q^{\prime},b\in Q^{\prime}\setminus Q. Construct flow network G′​(V′,E′)superscript𝐺′superscript𝑉′superscript𝐸′G^{\prime}(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}) and apply Ford & Fulkerson Algorithm [13] to compute the max flow.

  2. 2.

    Once we find nodes a,b𝑎𝑏a,b where κ​(a,b)≤k𝜅𝑎𝑏𝑘\kappa(a,b)\leq k, use the min cut of the flow network as separator S¯¯𝑆\bar{S}. Remove S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} and obtain several subgraphs. Add S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} back to each subgraph and mark S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} as “separator”. Return the subgraphs for screening.

  3. 3.

    Otherwise, G𝐺G is k𝑘k-robust and output it as a k𝑘k-core.

Example 4.16.

Continue with Example 4.14 and k=2𝑘2k=2. There are four 3-connected v-unions. When we check r1∈Q1subscript𝑟1subscript𝑄1r_{1}\in Q_{1} and r6∈Q3subscript𝑟6subscript𝑄3r_{6}\in Q_{3}, we find S¯={r3,r4}¯𝑆subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟4\bar{S}=\{r_{3},r_{4}\}. We then split G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} into subgraphs {r1−r4}subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟4\{r_{1}-r_{4}\} and {r3−r6}subscript𝑟3subscript𝑟6\{r_{3}-r_{6}\}, marking r3subscript𝑟3r_{3} and r4subscript𝑟4r_{4} as “separators”.

Now consider graph G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} in Figure 2 and k=2𝑘2k=2. There are four 3-connected v-unions (actually four v-cliques) and six pairs of adjacent v-unions. For Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} and Q2subscript𝑄2Q_{2}, we check nodes r2subscript𝑟2r_{2} and r4subscript𝑟4r_{4} and find κ​(r2,r4)=3𝜅subscript𝑟2subscript𝑟43\kappa(r_{2},r_{4})=3. Similarly we check for every other pair of adjacent v-unions and decide that the graph is 2-robust. □□\Box

Proposition 4.17.

Let p𝑝p be the total number of pairs of adjacent v-unions, and g𝑔g be the number of nodes in the input graph. Algorithm Split runs in time O​(p​g2.5)𝑂𝑝superscript𝑔2.5O(pg^{2.5}). □□\Box

Proof 4.18.

Authors in [9] proves that it takes in time O​(g2.5)𝑂superscript𝑔2.5O(g^{2.5}) to compute κ​(a,b)𝜅𝑎𝑏\kappa(a,b) for a pair of nodes a𝑎a and b𝑏b in G𝐺G. In the worst case Split needs to compute κ​(a,b)𝜅𝑎𝑏\kappa(a,b) for p𝑝p pairs of adjacent v-unions. Thus, Split runs in time O​(p​g2.5)𝑂𝑝superscript𝑔2.5O(pg^{2.5}).

Recall that if we solve the Max-Flow Problem directly for each pair of sources in the original graph, the complexity is O​(|L¯|4.5)𝑂superscript¯𝐿4.5O(|\bar{L}|^{4.5}), which would be dramatically higher.

4.3.3 Full algorithm

We are now ready to present the full algorithm, Core (Algorithm 3). Initially, it initializes the working queue 𝐐𝐐\bf Q with only input G𝐺G (Line 1). Each time it pops a subgraph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} from 𝐐𝐐\bf Q and invokes Screen (Lines 3-4). If the output of Screen is still G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} (so G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} is a (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-overlap subgraph) (Line 5), it removes any node with mark “separator” in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} and puts the new subgraph into the working queue (Line 7), or invokes Split on G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} if there is no separator (Line 9). Subgraphs output by Screen and Split are added to the queue for further examination (Lines 10, 13) and identified cores are added to C¯¯𝐶\bar{C}, the core set. It terminates when 𝐐=∅𝐐\bf Q=\emptyset.

The correctness of algorithm Core is guaranteed by the following Lemmas.

Lemma 4.19.

For each pair of adjacent nodes r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} in graph G𝐺G, there exists a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning such that r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} are in the same subgraph. □□\Box

Proof 4.20.

For each pair of adjacent nodes r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} in G𝐺G, we prove the existence of such a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning by constructing it.

By definition, adjacent node r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime} form a v-clique C𝐶C. Therefore, there exists a maximal v-clique C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} in G𝐺G that contains r,r′𝑟superscript𝑟′r,r^{\prime}, i.e., C⊆C′𝐶superscript𝐶′C\subseteq C^{\prime}. V-clique C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} can be obtained by keep adding nodes in G𝐺G to C𝐶C so that each newly-added node is adjacent to each node in current clique until no nodes in G𝐺G can be added to C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}. By definition, any v-clique is k𝑘k-robust, therefore there exists a maximal k𝑘k-robust sub-graph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} in G𝐺G such that C′⊆G′superscript𝐶′superscript𝐺′C^{\prime}\subseteq G^{\prime}. Graph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} can be obtained by keep adding nodes in G𝐺G to C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime} so that each newly-added node is adjacent to at least k+1𝑘1k+1 nodes in current graph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} until no nodes in G𝐺G can be added to G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}. We remove G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} from G𝐺G and take G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} as a subgraph in the desired partitioning.

We repeat the above process to a randomly-selected pair of adjacent nodes in the remaining graph G∖G′𝐺superscript𝐺′G\setminus G^{\prime} until it is empty. The desired partitioning satisfies Condition 1 and 2 of Definition 4.2 because the above process makes sure each subgraph is exclusive and k𝑘k-robust; it satisfies Condition 3 of Definition 4.2 because the above process makes sure each subgraph is maximal, which means merging arbitrary number of subgraphs in the partitioning would violate Condition 2.

In summary, the desired partitioning is a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning. It proves that for each pair of adjacent nodes r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} in graph G𝐺G, there exists a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning such that r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are in the same subgraph.

Lemma 4.21.

The set of nodes in a separator S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} of graph G𝐺G does not belong to any k𝑘k-core in G𝐺G, where |S¯|≤k¯𝑆𝑘|\bar{S}|\leq k. □□\Box

Proof 4.22 (Lemma 4.21).

Suppose the set S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} of nodes separate G𝐺G into m𝑚m disconnected sets X¯i,i∈[1,m],m>0formulae-sequencesubscript¯𝑋𝑖𝑖1𝑚𝑚0\bar{X}_{i},i\in[1,m],m>0. To prove that each node r∈S¯𝑟¯𝑆r\in\bar{S} does not belong to any k𝑘k-core in G𝐺G, we prove that for a node r′∈G,r′≠rformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑟′𝐺superscript𝑟′𝑟r^{\prime}\in G,r^{\prime}\neq r, there exists a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning such that r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are separated. Node r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} falls into the following cases: 1) r′∈X¯i,i∈[1,m]formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑟′subscript¯𝑋𝑖𝑖1𝑚r^{\prime}\in\bar{X}_{i},i\in[1,m] ; 2) r′∈S¯superscript𝑟′¯𝑆r^{\prime}\in\bar{S}.

Consider Case 1) where r′∈X¯i,i∈[1,m]formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑟′subscript¯𝑋𝑖𝑖1𝑚r^{\prime}\in\bar{X}_{i},i\in[1,m]. We construct a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning of G𝐺G where r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are in different subgraphs. We start with a maximal k𝑘k-robust subgraph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} in G𝐺G that contains r𝑟r and r′′superscript𝑟′′r^{\prime\prime} where r′′superscript𝑟′′r^{\prime\prime} is adjacent to r𝑟r and in X¯j,j≠i,j∈[1,m]formulae-sequencesubscript¯𝑋𝑗𝑗𝑖𝑗1𝑚\bar{X}_{j},j\neq i,j\in[1,m], and find other maximal k𝑘k-robust subgraphs as in Lemma 4.19. Since S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} separates X¯isubscript¯𝑋𝑖\bar{X}_{i} and X¯jsubscript¯𝑋𝑗\bar{X}_{j}, maximal k𝑘k-robust subgraph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} that contains r𝑟r and r′′superscript𝑟′′r^{\prime\prime} does not contain any node in X¯isubscript¯𝑋𝑖\bar{X}_{i}. It proves that there exists a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning of G𝐺G where r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are not in the same subgraph.

Consider Case 2) where r′∈S¯superscript𝑟′¯𝑆r^{\prime}\in\bar{S}. We construct a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning of G𝐺G such that r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are in different subgraphs. We create two maximal k𝑘k-robust subgraphs G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} and G′′superscript𝐺′′G^{\prime\prime}, where G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} contains r𝑟r and an adjacent node ri∈X¯i,i∈[1,m]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑟𝑖subscript¯𝑋𝑖𝑖1𝑚r_{i}\in\bar{X}_{i},i\in[1,m], G′′superscript𝐺′′G^{\prime\prime} contains r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} and an adjacent node rj∈X¯j,j≠i,j∈[1,m]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑟𝑗subscript¯𝑋𝑗formulae-sequence𝑗𝑖𝑗1𝑚r_{j}\in\bar{X}_{j},j\neq i,j\in[1,m]. We create other subgraphs as in Lemma 4.19. Since each path between ri∈X¯isubscript𝑟𝑖subscript¯𝑋𝑖r_{i}\in\bar{X}_{i} and rj∈X¯jsubscript𝑟𝑗subscript¯𝑋𝑗r_{j}\in\bar{X}_{j} contains at least one node in S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} and |S¯|≤k¯𝑆𝑘|\bar{S}|\leq k, graph G′∪G′′superscript𝐺′superscript𝐺′′G^{\prime}\cup G^{\prime\prime} is not k𝑘k-robust. Therefore, the created partitioning is a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning. It proves that there exists a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning of G𝐺G where r𝑟r and r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} are not in the same subgraph.

Given the above two cases, we have that any node in separator S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} of G𝐺G does not belong to any k𝑘k-core in G𝐺G, where |S¯|≤k¯𝑆𝑘|\bar{S}|\leq k.

Theorem 4.22.

Let G𝐺G be the input graph and q𝑞q be the number of (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions in G𝐺G. Define a,p,g,m,𝑎𝑝𝑔𝑚a,p,g,m, and |L¯|¯𝐿|\bar{L}| as in Proposition 4.9 and 4.17. Algorithm Core finds correct k𝑘k-cores of G𝐺G in time O​(q​((m2+a)​|L¯|+p​g2.5))𝑂𝑞superscript𝑚2𝑎¯𝐿𝑝superscript𝑔2.5O(q((m^{2}+a)|\bar{L}|+pg^{2.5})) and is order independent. □□\Box

Proof 4.23.

We first prove that Core correctly finds k𝑘k-cores in G𝐺G, that is 1) nodes not returned by Core do not belong to any k𝑘k-core; 2) each subgraph returned by Core forms a k𝑘k-core.

We prove that nodes not returned by Core do not belong to any k𝑘k-core in G𝐺G. Nodes not returned by Core belong to separators of subgraphs in G𝐺G. Suppose S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} is a separator of graph Gn∈𝐐subscript𝐺𝑛𝐐G_{n}\in\bf Q found in either Screen or Split phase, where Gn⊆G,n≥0,G0=Gformulae-sequencesubscript𝐺𝑛𝐺formulae-sequence𝑛0subscript𝐺0𝐺G_{n}\subseteq G,n\geq 0,G_{0}=G, and S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} separates Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n} into m𝑚m sub-graphs X¯ni,i∈[1,m],m>1formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript¯𝑋𝑛𝑖𝑖1𝑚𝑚1\bar{X}_{n}^{i},i\in[1,m],m>1. Graph Gni∈𝐐superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖𝐐G_{n}^{i}\in\bf Q is a subgraph of Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n} such that any node r∈X¯nj,j∈[1,m],j≠iformulae-sequence𝑟superscriptsubscript¯𝑋𝑛𝑗formulae-sequence𝑗1𝑚𝑗𝑖r\in\bar{X}_{n}^{j},j\in[1,m],j\neq i does not belong to Gnisuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖G_{n}^{i}. Nodes removed in Gnisuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖G_{n}^{i} by Core belong to separator S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} in Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n}. Given Lema 4.21, such nodes do not belong to any k𝑘k-core in Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n} and thus does not belong to any k𝑘k-core in G𝐺G.

We next prove that each subgraph returned by Core forms a k𝑘k-core in G𝐺G. We prove two cases: 1) subgraph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} in G𝐺G forms a k𝑘k-core if there exists a separator S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} that disconnects G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} from G𝐺G, where |S¯|≤k¯𝑆𝑘|\bar{S}|\leq k and G′∪S¯superscript𝐺′¯𝑆G^{\prime}\cup\bar{S} and G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} are both k𝑘k-robust; 2) if a subgraph is a k𝑘k-core in Gnisuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖G_{n}^{i}, it is a k𝑘k-core in graph Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n}.

We consider Case 1) that subgraph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} in G𝐺G forms a k𝑘k-core if there exists a separator S¯¯𝑆\bar{S} that disconnects G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} from G𝐺G, where |S¯|≤k¯𝑆𝑘|\bar{S}|\leq k and G′∪S¯superscript𝐺′¯𝑆G^{\prime}\cup\bar{S} and G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} are both k𝑘k-robust. For a pair of nodes r1,r2subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2r_{1},r_{2} in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}, we prove that there exists no maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning where r1subscript𝑟1r_{1} and r2subscript𝑟2r_{2} are in different subgraphs. Suppose such a partitioning exists, and G1,G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1},G_{2} are subgraphs containing r1,r2subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2r_{1},r_{2} respectively. Since G1,G2⊆G′∪S¯subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2superscript𝐺′¯𝑆G_{1},G_{2}\subseteq G^{\prime}\cup\bar{S}, we have that G1∪G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1}\cup G_{2} is k𝑘k-robust, it violates the fact that the result of merging any two subgraphs in a maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning is not k𝑘k-robust. Therefore, there exists no maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning where r1subscript𝑟1r_{1} and r2subscript𝑟2r_{2} are in different subgraphs. It proves that G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} is a k𝑘k-core in G𝐺G.

We next consider Case 2) that if a subgraph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} is a k𝑘k-core in Gnisuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖G_{n}^{i}, it is a k𝑘k-core in graph Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n}. We prove that a pair of nodes r1,r2∈G′subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2superscript𝐺′r_{1},r_{2}\in G^{\prime} belong to the same subgraph of all maximal k𝑘k-robust partitioning in Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n}. Suppose there exists such a partitioning of Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n} where r1∈G1,r2∈G2formulae-sequencesubscript𝑟1subscript𝐺1subscript𝑟2subscript𝐺2r_{1}\in G_{1},r_{2}\in G_{2}. Since Gni⊆X¯ni∪S¯superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript¯𝑋𝑛𝑖¯𝑆G_{n}^{i}\subseteq\bar{X}_{n}^{i}\cup\bar{S}, we have G1,G2⊆Gnisubscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖G_{1},G_{2}\subseteq G_{n}^{i}, otherwise G1,G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1},G_{2} are not k𝑘k-robust. Since r1,r2subscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2r_{1},r_{2} belong to the same k𝑘k-core in Gnisuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖G_{n}^{i}, we have G1=G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1}=G_{2}. It proves that if G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} is a k𝑘k-core in Gnisuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖G_{n}^{i}, it is a k𝑘k-core in Gnsubscript𝐺𝑛G_{n}.

The above two cases prove that each subgraph returned by Core forms a k𝑘k-core in G𝐺G. In summary, nodes not returned by Core do not belong to any k𝑘k-core, and each subgraph returned by Core forms a k𝑘k-core in G𝐺G. Thus, Core correctly finds all k𝑘k-cores in G𝐺G. It further proves that the result of Core is independent from the order in which we find and remove separators of graphs in 𝐐𝐐\bf Q.

We now analyze the time complexity of Core. For each (k+1)𝑘1(k+1)-connected v-unions in G𝐺G, it takes in time O​(m2+a)​|L¯|𝑂superscript𝑚2𝑎¯𝐿O(m^{2}+a)|\bar{L}| to proceed Screen phase and in time O​(p​g2.5)𝑂𝑝superscript𝑔2.5O(pg^{2.5}) to proceed Split phase. In total there are q𝑞q v-unions in G𝐺G, thus the algorithm takes in time O​(q​((m2+a)​|L¯|+p​g2.5))𝑂𝑞superscript𝑚2𝑎¯𝐿𝑝superscript𝑔2.5O(q((m^{2}+a)|\bar{L}|+pg^{2.5})).

Example 4.24.

First, consider graph G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} in Figure 2 and k=2𝑘2k=2. Table 4 shows the step-by-step core identification process. It passes screening and is the input for split. Split then splits it into G21superscriptsubscript𝐺21G_{2}^{1} and G22superscriptsubscript𝐺22G_{2}^{2}, where r3subscript𝑟3r_{3} and r4subscript𝑟4r_{4} are marked as “separators”. Screen further splits each of them into {r3}subscript𝑟3\{r_{3}\} and {r4}subscript𝑟4\{r_{4}\}, both discarded as each represents a single node (and is a separator). So Core does not output any core.

Next, consider the motivating example, with the input shown in Table 3 and k=1𝑘1k=1. Originally, 𝐐={G}𝐐𝐺{\bf Q}=\{G\}. After invoking Screen on G𝐺G, we obtain three subgraphs G1,G2,superscript𝐺1superscript𝐺2G^{1},G^{2}, and G3superscript𝐺3G^{3}. Screen outputs G1superscript𝐺1G^{1} and G3superscript𝐺3G^{3} as 1-cores since each contains a single node that represents multiple records. It further splits G2superscript𝐺2G^{2} into two single-node graphs G4superscript𝐺4G^{4} and G5superscript𝐺5G^{5}, and outputs the latter as a 1-core. Note that if we remove the 1-robustness requirement, we would merge r11−r18subscript𝑟11subscript𝑟18r_{11}-r_{18} to the same core and get false positives. □□\Box

Case study: On the data set with 18M records, our core-identification algorithm finished in 2.2 minutes. Screen was invoked 114K times and took 2 minutes (91%) in total. Except the original graph, an input contains at most 39.3K nodes; for 97% inputs there are fewer than 10 nodes and running Screen was very fast. Split was invoked only 26 times; an input contains at most 65 nodes (13 v-unions) and on average 7.8 (2.7 v-unions). Recall that the simplified inverted index contains 1.5M entries, so Screen reduced the size of the input to Split by 4 orders of magnitude.

5 Group Linkage

The second stage clusters the cores and the remaining records, which we call satellites, into groups. To avoid merging records based only on weak evidence, we require that a cluster cannot contain more than one satellite but no core. Comparing with clustering in traditional record linkage, our algorithm differs in three aspects. First, in addition to weighting each attribute, we weight the values according to their popularity within a group such that similarity on primary values (strong evidence) is rewarded more. Second, we treat all values for dominant-value attributes as a whole, we are tolerant to differences on local values from different entities in the same group. Third, we distinguish weights for distinct values and non-distinct values such that similarity on distinct values is rewarded more. This section first describes the objective function for clustering (Section 5.1) and then proposes a greedy algorithm for clustering (Section 5.2).

5.1 Objective function

SV-index: Ideally, we wish that each cluster is cohesive (each element, being a core or a satellite, is close to other elements in the same cluster) and different clusters are distinct (each element is fairly different from those in other clusters). Since records in the same group may have fairly different local values, we adopt Silhouette Validation Index (SV-index) [25] as the objective function as it is more tolerant to diversity within a cluster. Given a clustering 𝒞𝒞\cal C of elements 𝐄𝐄\bf E, the SV-index of 𝒞𝒞\cal C is defined as follows.

S​(𝒞)𝑆𝒞\displaystyle S(\cal C) =\displaystyle= A​v​ge∈𝐄​S​(e);𝐴𝑣subscript𝑔𝑒𝐄𝑆𝑒\displaystyle Avg_{e\in{\bf E}}S(e); (1)
S​(e)𝑆𝑒\displaystyle S(e) =\displaystyle= a​(e)−b​(e)+αmax⁡{a​(e),b​(e)}+β.𝑎𝑒𝑏𝑒𝛼𝑎𝑒𝑏𝑒𝛽\displaystyle\frac{a(e)-b(e)+\alpha}{\max\{a(e),b(e)\}+\beta}. (2)
